snippet: South Ossetia had high hopes when Russia took control of the enclave from Georgia in 2008, but its economy is stagnant and corruption is rife.
abstract: Enclave of South Ossetia, which Russia formally recognized as independent of Georgia in 2008, has closely watched Russian takeover of Crimea; South Ossetia's hopes that it would benefit from allegiance to Russia have gone mostly unrealized, while area has proven to be burden on Russia.

byline.original: By OLESYA VARTANYAN and ELLEN BARRY
byline.contributor: Olesya Vartanyan reported from Atotsi, and Ellen Barry from Moscow.

lead_paragraph: South Ossetia had high hopes when Russia took control of the enclave from Georgia in 2008, but its economy is stagnant and corruption is rife.

headline.main: If History Is a Guide, Crimeans’ Celebration May Be Short-Lived
headline.print_headline: If History Is a Guide, Crimeans’ Celebration May Be Short-Lived
